cards.title: Business context
cards.text-copy: Gain understanding of the business goals and priorities through stakeholder interviews and analysis

cards.title: Competitor analysis
cards.text-copy: Learn from how others have solved similar problems. Compare successful/unsucessful solutions

cards.title: Benchmark studies
cards.text-copy: Compare desired outcomes and features against industry standards

cards.title: Data analysis
cards.text-copy: See if you can find any useful data. Page views, clicks etc. Include big data, CRM systems or any existing data

cards.title: User journey maps (now)
cards.text-copy: Understand how users use the existing system by mapping out the user flows and pathways

cards.title: Content analysis
cards.text-copy: Understand existing content, affinities, and taxonomies,  e.g. via card sorting

cards.title: User feedback
cards.text-copy: Analyse existing user feedback, talk to customer service, look at reviews and ratings

cards.title: Emphathy map
cards.text-copy: Get stakeholders on the same page on who you are building the software forUnderstand existing content, affinities, and taxonomies,  e.g. via card sorting

cards.title: Task analysis
cards.text-copy: Detailed breakdown of user flows

cards.title: Context of use
cards.text-copy: Understand where, when and how users perform their tasks. Why are they performing their tasks? What are their goals? Do interviews, surveys, focus groups, or contextual inquiries

cards.title: Personas
cards.text-copy: Archetypal/proto personas - Descriptions of the user groups, subsequently developed into full personas. Variations: Proto personas, lean personas, MVP personas

cards.title: Moodboard
cards.text-copy: Moodboard TBD

cards.title: Service safari
cards.text-copy: Go through the user's journey yourself, immerse yourself in the experience and take notes

cards.title: Red routes
cards.text-copy: Identify key routes, what most users do often (or first), and prioritise these

cards.title: User experience maps
cards.text-copy: Understand individual's interactions and relationship with an organisation over time and across different channels

cards.title: Story mapping
cards.text-copy: Map out the steps and tasks that various users need to go through to achieve their goals. Define scope, plan and prioritise

cards.title: User stories
cards.text-copy: Write actionable user stories: As a [...], I want to [â€¦], so that I can [...]. Remember to have personas in mind when writing user stories

cards.title: Brainstorm and sketch
cards.text-copy: Invite people to UX workshops, bring stationery into a room to create, sketch and discuss ideas

cards.title: Scenarios
cards.text-copy: Map out potential scenarios that users might go through

cards.title: Navigation concepts
cards.text-copy: Create possible cognitive navigation patterns that align with users conceptual models

cards.title: OOUX (Object Oriented User Experience)
cards.text-copy: Identify cognitive objects and understand their relationships before designing the system

cards.title: Information architecture design
cards.text-copy: Understand the structure of content and data. How can you organise content and navigation in a consistent way that makes sense to users?

cards.title: User journey maps
cards.text-copy: Ideate on future user journeys matching the users workflows. Use storytelling to communicate redesigned user journeys

cards.title: System maps
cards.text-copy: Map objects and their relationships within a system to build a shared understanding with stakeholders and users

cards.title: See-do diagrams
cards.text-copy: Map out what users can see and do at each screen. Break it down into atoms.

cards.title: Wireframe
cards.text-copy: Structure content into layouts, that are aligned with your user flows.

cards.title: Prototype
cards.text-copy: Create quick paper prototypes or use tools to build interactive prototypes to test your ideas

cards.title: Gestures
cards.text-copy: If you design for mobile tablets, what gestures are avaialble? Pinch, drag, zoom? What if left-handed? What if users need voice interaction?

cards.title: Micro interactions
cards.text-copy: Introduce micro interactions to aid users to get feedback on what's happening and provide delightful surprises

cards.title: Transitions
cards.text-copy: Design transitions that help users understand the interactions and the outcomes

cards.title: Language
cards.text-copy: Speak the same language as your users. It should match what your company does, and the user demographics

cards.title: Tone of voice
cards.text-copy: Make sure the tone of voice and copywriting reflect the impression you're trying to create. E.g. friendly, formal, informal

cards.title: Waiting times
cards.text-copy: Inform the user on the current progress, make your application feel faster.

cards.title: Errors
cards.text-copy: Try to avoid users making errors, and if they do, make sure you help them recover from errors

cards.title: Completed actions
cards.text-copy: TBA

cards.title: Indicate status
cards.text-copy: Always show the state of the system to your users

cards.title: UI elements
cards.text-copy: Create styleguide and pattern libraries to keep the consistency and guide the UI design.

cards.title: Mockups
cards.text-copy: Create high fidelity visual mockups in order to communicate with the stakeholders and developers on how the system will look like.

cards.title: Use of images and icons
cards.text-copy: Use images and icons as visual cues to better guide the users.

cards.title: Responsive design
cards.text-copy: Design the system for the intended devices. Research whether they switch between devices.

cards.title: Font and colour hierarchy
cards.text-copy: Design a comprehensive and cohesive visual language. Keep it simple, stick to guidelines and use a limited number of sizes and colours. Consider accessibility constraints/requirements

cards.title: Accessibility
cards.text-copy: Research and consider accessibility constraints/requirements for your intended users

cards.title: Usability
cards.text-copy: Evaluate using the 10 heuristics
